Unexpectedly,there is a hair in the sealed packing bag .I did some research and Moroccianoil only sells to salons to prevent imposters like this.

  14. I thought the low price was fishy but crossed my fingers it was real. No such luck. The bottle did arrive quickly but the spilled concoction inside smelled of suntan oil and baby powder ? Something weird-- NOT the familiar scent of MorrocanOil. The bottle had a fake label that was similar to the real thing but poorly printed and designed differently. The big give away is the bottle though. The real thing comes in a brown bottle with the product name in raised letters right ON the glass-- as part of the actual bottle. If you got a plain brown bottle-- you got had.<br />On a positive note, they did refund my money ASAP. So whatever... They are trying to make some quick money and what better way than on the back of our beloved but way over priced M Oil! Good luck.

  35. I notice a real difference from the Morrocan Oil, which seems unique in it's ability to make my hair look smooth and camouflage my split ends. The only very minor downside is that, once you get it on your hands (which you'll need to do to apply it), it takes some washing and wiping to get it off your hands. The product has a distinctive but very pleasant musky smell. My stylist applies it before the blow-dryer and flat iron, and I have used a small amount at home on the ends of my dry hair to smooth down the frizzy ends. The bottle may seem expensive, but you only need a tiny amount each time.

  44. This is an exciting new (to me, at least) product made from the oil of a plant that is only found growing native to Morocco. At 59 my hair, once soft and lustrous, had become rather dry and frizzy. I went to the salon to get my long hair cut off trying to regain a bit of a youthful look. I left not only with a great haircut but I also learned about MoroccanOil. The stylist told me drier hair is common as one ages and used the oil on my hair. I was very pleased with the results. Used sparingly on wet hair before styling it gives a suppleness and shine that is not oily or greasy at all. The salon sells the oil for $30 something but I found it on Amazon for $27.50 plus free shipping! Seems the price on Amazon has gone up to just over $30 as I write this but it's still a wonderful product, to me well worth the cost and I'm not one to spend a lot on beauty products at all. The only reason I did not give it a full five stars is that the scent of the oil could be a bit more pleasant. I'd say it resembles the smell of chocolate a bit. Once styling product is applied, however, the scent is not that noticeable and certainly not a deterrent to using MoroccanOil.

Straightening irons smoothed the waves but frizz still prevailed. Need only a small amount of Moroccanoil distributed through clean, damp hair and then maybe a light touch after drying and styling. Then I usually brush my hair back in a smooth, low ponytail while I put on my make-up. When I let it loose after 10 minutes or so, it is even smoother. I have even gone out in damp and humid weather and it still looks good.   79. I have thick, curly hair as my title states. I've always used gel to keep the curls neat and control frizz. However, it's always been a balancing act. Too little and my curls are undefined and frizzy. Too much and it's crunchy. So hard to know where that middle line lies. My stylist pulled out this cream a few years back. I was super skeptical. Usually curl creams are too wimpy to manage my hair, and they just end up making it greasy. Well, I haven't used anything else in several years now. First, it smells awesome. Not too strong, but pleasant. Second, there is absolutely no crunch, just softness. Third, it keeps my curls really neat! Unbelievable. Finally, my hair never feels sticky or heavy. If I could design the perfect feel and effective cream it would be this cream. Totally worth the cost too, since I use one pump for a full head of curls.

This stuff is great & my husband (who never uses anything special on his hair) loves it too. And did I mention the scent? Heavenly!

It last a long time, just a little dab will do.   123. I have long hair (almost waist length)that is foil wrapped (highlighted) every 6 weeks and my hair texture is baby fine but lots of it so blow drying without frying it can be a challenge. I've used other \\"tamer\\" type products in the past but they seem geared only towards those with naturally curly, coarse type hair or something and weigh my baby locks down. This product gives me shine without weight and the very best thing, especially in winter, is that I'm not left with TONS of static cling in my hair after blow drying. It also seems to protect my hair from the heat of the blow dryer.<br /><br />This has worked for me even in the most humid weather. Another good thing is this product is so light that after using, I can curl my normally straight hair and it WILL curl and the curls last just as if I didn't use the product and I cannot say that about any other \\"tamer\\" type product I've ever used.<br /><br />The only downside to this product is that it is somewhat expensive but I've found that even though I do have lots of hair, a little less than a dime sized amount is plenty to get the results I want so the bottle does last a long time for me. Just pour a small amount in your hand, rub your palms together and apply to your hair. I do my ends first and work my way up to the crown, then blow dry as normal.

Rich in vitamin E, carotene, phenolic acid and essential fatty acids, argan oil is one of the rarest but most valuable cosmetic ingredients. This turns hair into silk, few small drops is all I need in the morning on freshly washed hair that's still wet or damp, and it vanished instantly, never making my hair greasy or heavy. When I wash it the next day I can still feel the extra softness but it's so marvelous that I tend to use it every day. So far in my life I haven't used an oil based product that vanishes so well, this really leaves no greasy residue whatsoever and the hair feels like spun silk, even my damaged ends feel more light and wispy, sometimes I feel like I cant stop touching my hair, to someone who doesn't know how well this works I might appear to have a disorder where my arm flies up to my hair all the time.... - Kasia S.

  150. I bought my Moroccanoil from a salon, and it's clear to me that it's the \\"real deal.\\" However, it contains very little real argan oil and mostly just the same inexpensive ingredients (they are listed on the box) that are found in most hair serums. A good thing, no doubt, as every time I've put pure oil in my hair to condition it, it's (understandably) looked greasy. Anyway, this stuff works fine, and if you compare it to John Frieda's serums, Bumble & Bumble Defrizz, Silk Therapy, etc., it is far superior. Personally, I find L'anza's Healing Moisture to make my hair appear healthier and shinier, and it \\"weightlessly disappears\\" into my hair just as well as does Moroccanoil. It also smells good, though Moroccanoil smells a bit more heavenly. Bottom line: if you don't mind paying an arm and a leg for an argan oil product that contains very little argan oil, it's good. It will also last you forever. However, if you want a product that makes your hair a bit healthier-looking and has more healing ingredients, and you want to get way more bang for your buck, try L'anza. For the record, if I couldn't get L'anza or if they doubled the price of their product, then I would DEFINITELY opt to use Moroccanoil over any other product out there. I took away 1 star because it is overpriced relative to the ingredients it contains. I took away another star because it doesn't make my hair look as awesome as L'anza's , which I've set as the gold standard. For the record, I have long, fine, smooth/straight/shiny, colored hair, and an oily scalp. Moroccanoil does not weigh my hair down, nor does it leave any residue on my hair. It really is a nice product; it's just not the best. UPDATE: I just received a large sample of Aquage's Silkening Oil Treatment, and it is a contender for my favorite hair serum--it's as good as L'Anza's, and possibly even cheaper! Oh, and it has argan oil in it as well, in case that ingredient is important to you.

It turns out perfect every time. If I still have a little frizz I use a VERY small amount of the Moroccanoil and then hairspray. It looks perfect all day.   184. I've been purchasing Moroccanoil for about a year now through amazon. It's difficult to get to the only store in the area who sales it. The real Moroccanoil is great. You do not need to use a lot (so the bottle lasts for sometime) and it improves the texture of my hair. My hair was usually dry and brittle, but this product has really provided moisture- without being greasy!!! It also speeds the drying time too somehow. I highly recommend giving it a try!! However as reviewers have posted there is a fake Moroccanoil out there. I happened to receive it around May of this year, and did not realize until I was reordering last week. When I received it I was a bit skeptical because some of the liquid had leaked from the bottle. Also it tended to be a LOT thicker than the original and had a different smell. I thought they had changed their formula (which I didn't like). I was going to try and find something else until I saw the negative reviews and then ordered from the first supplier that I used. I did not throw away the bad bottle so I compared it to my recent purchase. There are noticable differences. The easiest check is that on the real product, above the L on the white Moroccanoil writing on the bottle, has a (R)- for registered trademark. The supplier that I know has the good stuff (who I will continue to buy from) is BeautyClicks. It may be more expensive than some of the others, but I am confident that I am getting the right product and will not have to deal with the hassle of returning it. SO.. in conclusion.. The Real Moroccanoil is wonderful!!! But be warned there are fakes and you may have to spend more for the right stuff.

  335. Let me start off by saying I am a huge fan or Moroccan Oil treatments. It seems to be all the rage in beauty products right now and I've used everything from the Joico color therapy serum which is the oil in it(about $20 a bottle), this product (about $40), Organix Penetrating Moroccan Oil (around $7), and pure Moroccan Oil (anywhere from $20-40). While logically my favorite is the pure oil, let me state that if you are on a budget you should try the Organix Penetrating Moroccan Oil!! The ingredients of this Moroccan Oil product and the Organix product are nearly identical but the Organix oil is over 30 dollars less! These are the Moroccan Oil brand ingredients (3.4 oz bottle): Cyclopentasiloxane, Dimethicone, Cyclomethicone, Butylphenyl Methyl Propional, Argania Spinoza Kernel Oil (Aragan Oil), Linseed (Linum Usitatissimum) Extract, Fragrance Supplement, D & C Yellow 11, D & C Red 17, Coumarin, Benzyl Benzoate, Alpha-Isomethyl Ionone. These are the Organix brand ingredients (3.3 oz bottle): Cyclopentasiloxane, Dimethicone, Cyclomethicone, C12 15 Alkyl Benzoate, Butylphenyl Methlyproprional, Argania Spinosa (Argan) Kernel Oil (Argan), Linum Usitatissimum (Linseed) Extract (Linseed), Parfum, Yellow 11, Red 17 You make the call! I don't usually write reviews but I just wanted to let everyone know that there is a similar product out there for much less!

We use the hydrading mask, intense curl cream, shine spray, and of course the actual moroccan oil. I have super sensitive skin and I notice that I dont break out from using these products, but the mask can be heavy, so I wear my hair up at night and wash my hair at least 2x/wk. Since the 2 years, my hair has grown at least 2 feet, I get it cut frequently and loose about 4 inches every quarter, so...yeah, use this product if youre trying to grow your hair out ladies!!   356. I am a hair product junkie and this just didn't quite give me a fix. It's basically Frizz-ease with some added Argan oil. I was expected a higher concentration of the Argan oil, but it's 5th on the list of ingredients - a fair amount, but not for what you are paying. (the top 5 ingredients of any item are basically what make the product) If something is going to be called 'Moroccan Oil', you'd expect it to be just that, right?<br /><br />It's very smoothing (hence the silcones at the top of the list of ingredients). Silicones will build on the hair and will eventually have to be stripped with a detoxing shampoo to remove the build-up. I have virgin naturally curly bi-racial hair with a fine texture (think R&B singer Mya). Silicone build-up on curly hair can be the devil so curlies beware. The smell is not too bad. Kind of musky. Just glad that I purchased through Amazon and got a great deal (50% of the normal price).<br /><br />All in all, it Will suffice for a quick fix for minor frizz, but definitely not a 'treatment'. For that, I highly recommend Eden Allure. They have 100% pure Argan oil available and it doubles as skin care. (not affiliated-just a lover of natural products) Speaking of which, Moroccal oil has color additives (D&C Yellow 11 and Red 17).

  362. If you are an African American woman (or any ethnic woman) who has had RELAXERS and are going through the RELAXED to NATURAL transition? Do NOT waste your time buying this product unless you have the time, money, and patience to deal with your hair. This is NOT the product to use just a \\"dime sized amount\\" with when transitioning from relaxed to natural. I personally have thick hair to begin but when I did get relaxers, moisturizing was nothing and my hair held moisture just fine. In my current attempt to go \\"NATURAL\\", my hair is a giant sponge and this product does not and WILL not do anything luxurious for the new growth that is coming in like wild fire. The moisturizing has gotten worse and I find myself needing to moisturize TWICE a day and use more product than I have ever used :( My hair looks nothing like the sleek, shiny, and healthy hair that I have when I walk out of the salon after using this product. I'm not speaking for ALL women but mostly for those w/ thick, coarse hair AND for those who are in the relaxed to natural transitioning phase. I also have the moisturizing shampoo and conditioner and even those don't add the moisture that it claims to give. (At least not going through the transitioning phase). Now do NOT get me wrong, these products work WONDERFUL when your hairstylist is putting her hands to your hair and has all of the proper tools to get your hair bone straight and ultra glossy but, if you're attempting this at home? You may wanna find a better oil moisturizer that is truly going to help you through the transition :)

  364. For anyone with complaints about possibly getting fake Moroccan Oil online - my guess is it's factory related.<br /><br />I purchased the shampoo, conditioner, and oil a few months ago at a salon - smells like heaven, so indulgent!<br /><br />Then purchased the same items at the same salon today - smells/feels like completely different products with hardly any fragrance :(<br /><br />In order to determine the differences - I tested the older vrs newer product on each hand, and the older product was clearly more fragrant. The smell/consistency on the newer was just off, not thick and creamy as before. I also noticed the older bottle states, 'made in Canada' - and the new states, 'made in Israel' ...which leads me to believe they have production in both places.<br /><br />Therefore, this issue is not isolated to just orders placed online, but to salons as well, and, again, appears factory related.
  365. This is the SINGLE best purchase I have ever made in my life. Smells decadent, but doesn't \\"hang\\" in your hair... the smell eventually fades when it dries so it isn't overwhelming. Even my mother who is allergic to most smelly lotions, hair products and perfumes loooooves this oil. The oil pours out about the consistency of war m honey and soaks right into your hair without leaving it feeling greasy at all. I've been using it for about 2 weeks now, and the ONLY downside I can see to this product is that my hair doesn't hold a curl as well as it used to before I used the product, but if I strip my hair, I'm sure it will still curl... it's just made my hair just too damn healthy!
  366.   367. I have curly, frizzy, fine hair that I prefer to straighten, and on top of that, I color my hair, including two panels that get bleached and re-dyed purple. I spent the first 25 years of my life living in Atlanta, now I'm in New York City, so I know a few things about both damaged hair AND humidity. I've tried just about every brand of high-end hair products out there, in addition to a lot of drug store lines, and Moroccan Oil is the only thing that makes a truly noticeable difference in both my hair's texture and humidity resistance without making it a greasy mess. I've only been using it for a couple of weeks (I didn't believe the hype, so it took me a while to try it), but even after one use, I was thoroughly impressed. My hair just FELT healthier and blew out easier, which is something of a feat when you consider all the damage I've done to it. Plus it smells nice and you only need a little bit of product, so I couldn't be happier. I'm using it in conjunction with a Pureology product that helps repair bleached hair, and my results have been great.

  393. This item is counterfeit. The first time I purchase Moroccanoil was from a salon. It smelled amazing but not too overpowering it also did wonders for my hair! When I received my Moroccanoil from Amazon something was definitely wrong. The bottle was leaking when I opened the package. The smell oh it was horrid (a mix of babyoil, ban de soleil, and chemicals), so overpowering that I thought I was going to vomit. I knew something was off and didn't even think twice about putting that stuff into my hair. Since I already had an almost empty bottle that I bought from a legit salon I started to compare labels. The Moroccanoil purchased from Amazon was totally off the M on the front had an outline which the real bottle does not. On the back the most obvious is the fact that the counterfeit Moroccanoil doesn't have the Registered Trademark and Patent on it. Do not purchase this product, the Moroccanoil website has a salon locator that shows you nearest salons with their product. There's really no point in risking putting unknown chemicals into your hair.
  394. I am completely appalled that this company has the nerve to sell fake Moroccan Oil. When I purchased this item, a quarter of the bottle leaked in the container. I called and they refunded me the price for the spilled oil. Little did I know, until late, that the registered trademark symbol, which is located on all REAL Moroccanoil products was missing off the box of my product. I contacted Amazon, but they failed to address the issue. Looking at the comments of other people, it appears that they are aware that this company has been selling this fake product and yet they refuse to do anything about it. I guess when they get tired of refunding back the money through their A to Z Guarantee claim, then they will do something about this company who is obviously a joke. In other words, DO NO BUY THIS PRODUCT from Above ALL BEAUTY! It is not real.
  395. This product is full of artificial colourings and brought me up in spots. There are silicones in it which give a bit of a smooth finnish, but I can achieve that with cheap hair serum!   397. After stumbling across this product on Amazon, and seeing all of the amazing reviews, I decided Moroccanoil to spend the $35+ and give it a try. I went by a local salon, and they said they did not sell it, but that they had a couple of DermOrganic Argan oil treatment free samples sizes for me to try. Naturally, I gladly accepted since it was free. I have to say, I was REALLY impressed with the DermOrganic Argan oil - for all of the reasons that are listed in the Amazon reviews of their competitor product Moroccanoil. It made my hair healthy, shiny, and very managable. My hair almost felt hydrated when dry, yet very smooth. Still, memories of phenomenol Amazon reviews of Moroccanoil still danced in my head, so about three weeks ago when my samples ran out, I purchased and received my first bottle of Moroccanoil from Amazon. Honestly, I've been using the MoroccanOil product for 3 weeks now and I am not in the least bit impressed, and surprised by my disappointment. It doesn't make my hair nearly as shiny and soft as the DermOrganic Argan Oil samples from the local salon. It doesn't make my hair feel hydrated at all - rather it just feels like I have product on it. My hair actually looks a little dull! In fact, I'd say it's a step down from BioSilk (what I've used for 3 years) so far. Even though I still have a lot of MoroccanOil left, I actually went back to the salon tonight, thanked them again for the samples they gave me before, and purchased a larger bottle of the DermOrganic Argan oil treatment to use instead. (As a side note, DermOrganic costs about the same. I'm a penny pincher, and normally I would just finish the product I have to save money. The fact I bought DermOrganic even though I still have so much of the MoroccanOil left is definitely saying something about my experiences with both products.) Given all of the wonderful reviews of Moroccanoil, and the fact that most of the negative reviews of Moroccanoil were from people who had received a counterfeit from Amazon, I almost wonder if the bottle I received from Amazon this month is a counterfeit also. If I had more time to look into it further, I would - just out of curiosity and principal at this point. However, I work long hours and unless I get some free time, I'm going to keep using the DermOrganic argan oil treatment, since I'm really happy with that product and does everything that the reviewers describe of Moroccanoil. All in all, I hope other buyers have better experiences than I. If not, it may be worth trying DermOrganic Argan Oil.

  421. I admit that this product is good but it's certainly not the best product out there for what it does. I purchased a bottle of Moroccanoil about a month ago after much debate because the concept of adding oil to keep my hair soft and frizz free is not new to me. I am currently using Fredrick Fekkai Glossing Cream and love the product but I finally broke down and decided to give Moroccanoil a try because of all the great reviews here and on the internet. When I received the Moroccanoil I decided to put the product to the test to see what it can do, so after washing and towel drying my hair I divided my hair into two pig tails and used the Moroccanoil on one side and Fredrick Fekkai Glossing Cream on the other side. I then allowed my hair to air dry (as I usually do) and compared the results. The result was there was not a noticeable difference between the two sides, basically both sides of my hair were soft and frizz free. My second test was to use the Moroccanoil by itself, with no Fredrick Fekkai Glossing Cream at all. I washed and towel dried my hair, applied only the Moroccanoil and then allowed my hair to air dry. The result was some of my hair was frizzy, other parts were oily looking and yet other parts were soft and frizz free. I decided to repeat this test again later in the week under the assumption that I perhaps I used too much oil or didn't spread it out enough but the ended up with the same results. The last test I tried was to use the Moroccanoil with Fredrick Fekkai Glossing Cream together which resulted in my hair being frizz free, and not oily. The problem I have with Moroccanoil is most of the time it seems to work well only when combined with Fredrick Fekkai Glossing Cream and when I am able to finally get this product to work by itself the results are similar to Fredrick Fekkai Glossing Cream. Other disadvantages I have found with Moroccanoil is the glass jar and the control factor when you pour out the oil. Becauseit's liquid oil (unlike oil in a cream base) I found that it's easy to pour the product out too quickly. Also the Moroccanoil is not something I have found for sale other than on the internet. My conclusion is for MY hair the Moroccanoil doesn't spread well by itself and when it does it requires the aid of another product. The results are similar to a product I currently already use (Fredrick Fekkai Glossing Cream), is not a better price, is harder to use and is not readily available for purchase. I'll be sticking to my Fredrick Fekkai Glossing Cream.

  459. Ok this is my story. I love my stylist, he is a creative genious, amazing person, and is one of the few that understands my super long, but super fine, wavy hair that I wear stick straight most of the time. So what do I when he goes on vacation and I need to get my hair done asap? I go find a cheaper stylist and cheat on him. Yes, stupid, I know. That other stylist saw that I had a little bit of frizz and suggested one of those brazilian anti frizz treatments and told him to go ahead, I mean, what was the worst that could happen? Well, he fried my hair, not the whole hair, but parts of it, and ever since that happened I have been devastated. Thankfully, my stylist is back and I saw him a couple of days ago, I told him I was sorry, he hugged me (how forgiving lol) and told me don't worry wash your hair a couple of times with clarifying shampoo, use a deep conditioning mask, and take this bottle of moroccanoil treatment, use a tiny bit of moroccan oil on your wet hair before styling and a tiny bit after. I was leery about trying moroccan oil again. I bought it online before and hated it; the smell was very strong and the texture was thick and full of silicone. But I followed my stylist's advice and did what he told me last night. It worked! My hair is 90% better and not only that, I love my moroccanoil now! This makes me wonder if I unknownly bought a fake when I tried it the first time. I probably did. The bottle I bought at the salon had a softer smell and it was not as thick and greasy as the one I bought online so please be careful if buying this product online. The one I bought at the salon was the real thing. And also, never cheat on your stylist, even if the other one is cheap and looks good. ; )

People think I'm a straight haired girl. It smells nice. FYI --You might want to read the list of ingredients -- the argan oil is listed as about the 4th ingredient in the bottle.... so I dont think it's the argan oil that is doing the trick out of this bottle. Also, this stuff is ridiculously expensive but it is very popular because it works so well. I have found that sellers and retailers charge all kinds of crazy prices ripping customers off and a lot of reviewers say they receive fake product. I just bought a bottle from Ricky's and they charged me $49 before taxes-- which is 10% more than what the Moroccan oil website charges. So Ricky's is ripping people off on an already expensive product. (FYI Ricky's is a big beauty store in NYC) So -- I recommend you go to the Moroccan Oil website and order from them directly. That way you are sure you are getting the real product for the real price.

  552. My stylist turned me onto this product. It REALLY works. Apply a small amount to damp hair after shampooing (don't use any conditioner) and style as usual - blow dry or not. On all but the rainiest of days, this will keep your hair from frizzing up. Place your palm over the open bottle and invert to place a dime-sized amount onto your hand. Rub your hands together and spread through your hair. I have chin length, very thick hair and do this twice. That's all you need. No more conditioners, gels, sprays, that don't work anyway. The 3.4 oz. bottle will last a long time. The aroma is slightly musky but not overpowering and wears off fairly quickly. This will not stain your pillow or clothes. Enjoy!
  553. Since I have been using this product my hair curls together into smooth curls instead of the frizzy mess it was. I have since been wearing my hair down a lot instead of pulling it into a bun every day. I love this stuff!!!!!
  554. I have problematic, thin, curly hair. This product did not weigh my hair down the way most products do. It's got a discreet pleasant smell too. Hair felt softer and did not get weighed down even after multiple uses in a row. I recommend it.
  555. The only complaint I have is that some of the oil spilled out before I received it. Also, it will take a bit longer to ship if you live on my side of the country. Alas, my newest stylist recommended this to me. It makes my hair soft, easy to style and shiny without weighing it down. It's better for your hair than natural oil, in my opinion. I haven't had a trim in over six weeks and my split-ends are minimal. Salons will sell this bottle to you for about $40 bucks and I got mine off of here for $25 so it's worth buying from these people. I have straight hair but since it reduces drying time, I can fully dry it and style in less time. One of my best friends has thick curly hair and used it. Her hair looked amazing with just a dime-size amount and her curls were more defined. She plans to order a bottle as well. After using this, all I need is some hairspray to style and I'm ready to go.   683. Love, Love, Love this product! I kept going back to an expensive hair dresser because everytime I left my hair felt so buttery soft but it was the Moroccanoil she was using in my hair!! I purchased this from her for $31, so Amazon is a little cheaper- but don't forget the s/h. My Hair; Long 5-7\\" Past Sholders Semi-Wavy, gets frizzy brushed without a straight iron Med. Thickness I put the oil in my hair wet and use about .75tsp, I work it in through the ends first(I like to use a lot, plus my hair is long, you might want to try using less until you figure out what works for you).... then after it is dried and styled(usually flat ironed) I put about a nickel size amount through to tame the fly aways. Make sure you start at your ends so your roots don't get greasy or build up over time and rub the oil together in your palms before putting it in your hair for a more even coat. It also leaves my hair very shiny but not greasy looking- it looks healthy. I have been using this oil for about 2 months and my hair feels stronger too.   688. I bought this as a hair treatment, and for an occasional fix, it is excellent. I give it 5 stars for taming frizzy hair, being easy to use and smelling great. I keep this on hand for quick fixes, when I'm going out and want my hair to look (and smell!) great. Perfect for that. However, I would not use it after every shampoo, as it builds up on your hair. But if you use it after every shampoo, I recommend using B00099E8ZA once a week to remove all residue. This will truly clean your hair and you can use the Moroccan oil regularly and not have the problems other reviewers have mentioned, and get the great benefits.<br /><br />Back to Moroccan oil. Like I said, 5 stars (and more if I could) for the great effect it has on your hair. Will continue to use it. I take away a star, because, like other reviewers, I'm not impressed with the ingredients. I like natural ingredients, and if you say a product is Moroccan oil, than that should be the first ingredient. I use a product for skin care [[ASIN:B007VEPVZC Bel Essence - (2oz) 100% All-Natural, Organic Anti-Wrinkle Oil Treatment with Argan, Grapeseed and Avocado Oil]], and discovered after several months, that my eyelashes were longer and fuller, and my eyebrows were growing in better. It's 5 plant oils (including organic argan oil) - that's all, no other ingredients, all natural. I gave myself an oil treatment on my hair with it, just to try it out let sit for 15 minutes and then shampooed as usual, and my hair was noticeably softer. I do this once a week or so to see what it will do for my hair. This is the best skin care - slow change over a couple of months, but after about a week, your skin isn't dry, and stays moisturized, after a couple of months, your skin is soft, lines are less noticeable.

  720. I've been using this product for almost one year. I discovered Moracconoil when my hairdresser used it on my hair, and I loved the way it smelled and how soft it made my hair. I bought some to use at home because I have very dry hair in the winter (static, brittle ends, everything). That was last winter. At first it worked great and I noticed a big improvement in my hair. This summer, I noticed that my hair was feeling really dry again but I kept using the Moracconoil. I recently read a review of Moracconoil on a beauty blog that explains why it has stopped working. Moracconoil is full of silicone, which coats your hair, preventing moisture from reaching your hair and making your hair drier. If you want to use this product regularly, you need to use a clarifying shampoo.

I woke up late so I wasnt able to style it, but I did notice my hair feeling very soft. For trial #2, I put about 4 pumps in my hair (like I said, it's very long and fairly thick) and made sure to blow it dry. I can't really explain why, but I swear it made my hair feel dry, but at the same time, there was less frizz. This phenomenon happened the next time I blow dried and curled it as well. Lastly, I applied the product, let my hair dry overnight, and straightened it the next morning. I have the best results with this method, as my hair feels very soft and has less frizz.<br /><br />Overall, I was looking for a product to decrease frizz, make styling easier and moisture my hair. For me, Moroccanoil is just so-so and not worth the high price tag.   819. This is a FAKE! Moroccanoil is extremely strict about its retailing. Salons have to sign waivers agreeing that they will not sell at discounted rates. Have you ever noticed how Moroccanoil is never on sale at salons? Only certified salons can sell Moroccanoil products, so anything Moroccanoil sold online will virtually be a fake product. I had to learn the hard way, unfortunately.

My sister, who has the same type of hair, was using a spray in gel product that is available in most stores, and it was drying up her ends and breaking her hair off, in addition to being a hot mess after sleeping, forcing her to wash it every day if she wanted to avoid a bad hair day. I told her to try this and now she is using it herself - and loves it, too!
  1105. The girl that does my hair uses this in her salon. When I asked her what she put on my hair each time to make it feel so silky, she showed me the oil in the blue bottle/box. She said it was pricey but it took only a small amt (dime size). So I purchased the Moroccan Oil from Amazon (was cheaper here than anywhere else). This stuff is great. It makes my hair feel so good and it is healthy for your hair especially if you blow dry or use a curling/flat iron. And it doesn't take very much @ all to make your hair feel silky until you shampoo it again. They have Moroccan Oil in stores like Wal-Mart and Wal-Greens but it's not the real oil. I will definitely continue to purchase this for my hair.

I straighten and blow dry daily, so there's a bit of heat damage. I put a drop of Moroccan Oil (dime-sized or smaller) in my hand and then run my hand through my hair, avoiding the roots. You can do this on wet or dry hair. Immediately, you see added shine, less frizz, and a whiff of the incredible scent meets your nose. It has never made my hair appear oily, although I could see how it might if you use too much.<br /><br />This product might seem expensive, but I assure you it lasts a great deal of time.   1127. Alright my lovely Glamazons. By now you know that I am not only a licensed Hair stylist and Makeup Artist to some of the biggest names, but I am one of the most trusted on product knowledge. You also know that I am not paid for endorsements and I'm unbiased. Moroccan Oil was exciting when it first launched at our industry trade show, Premiere, in Orlando, Fl. They had demo's on the spot, and handed out mini sample bottles to everyone with their grubby little hands out, mine included. As I researched this product and its ingredients a little deeper, I discovered that it is only a subtle, temporary fix for giving a little smoothing effect to the hair. There is no long term benefits from using this product. Don't waste your money. Yes, it smells nice, but it's not what it claims to be. No, I'm not hating on Moroccan Oil. There is nothing wrong with using it if you are just looking for a subtle and temporary fix and don't mind spending the money. You could get better results with pure organic coconut oil (used in small amounts). Now that I've told you the truth about this product, I will be honest and say I love their hairsprays and glimmer shine spray. You'll have to read those reviews there. If you want an alternative to this oil, Orofluido is much better, smells better and has more lasting results. Be sure to read my reviews before purchasing any hair product. I will ALWAYS give you an honest, educated and professional review. Til next time, smoochie smooch!<br /><br />Licensed Beauty Pro/ owner of Glamour Couture PA,NJ,NY

  1230. I discovered Moroccan Oil while serving as a bridesmaid in a wedding 3 years ago and I've used it every day since! I have very, very thick hair and it can be a little dry and brittle at times. It is also naturally curly, and even though I straighten it daily, the southern humidity can cause it to frizz. All of these issues were solved when I started using Moroccan Oil! I use it three different ways:<br />1. I put two pumps on my wet hair right after getting out of the shower. It is strong stuff, so it doesn't take much.<br />2. I put one more pump on my hair after styling it if the humidity is high that day.<br />3. If my hair is especially dry I use it as a hair 'mask' at night. I put several pumps on my dry hair and sleep with it on. The next morning my hair is soft and no longer dry. Works every time! :)

  1360. PLEASE don't fall for this or any other &#34;Moroccan Argan OIl&#34; scams. I just returned from Morocco, where I hiked the Atlas Mountains and visited cooperatives of women who hand-press real argan oil from the seed of the argan tree after shelling each one. Argan oil has become such a faddish Western craze that even in Morocco, the cities' medinas (central squares where merchants gather to sell their wares, in the case of argan essentially to tourists) are full of fake argan oil sellers, whose products are actually vegetable oil with perhaps a touch of argan. The production of real argan oil is labor-intensive and the product, even in Morroccan dirhans (the counrty's currency) is relatively costly. Still, I purchased a 25 oz. bottle of pure argan oil (which in its' natural state is cloudy and must be shaken before use) for the equivalent of 30 US dollars. (The argan used for the face and body is uncooked; there is another version of the oil, roasted and darker, used for cooking and high in mono-unsaturates, like olive oil, that is equally costly).<br /> The &#34;M - Moroccanoil&#34; line is, like almost all available &#34;argan&#34; products, a complete rip-off. Dimethicone and other silicone-derived products were found long ago to enhance hairs' pliability, softness, silkiness and combability. Nearly every effective conditioner, from Pantene to the most ridiculously overprices brands, depend on some version of silicates to effect the softness and &#34;silkiness&#34; Americans have come to expect from conditioners. (Brands which are &#34;natural&#34; and free of silicone produce a similar effect from alternative slippery ingredients). Argan oil is exactly what is sounds like -- an OIL. When you put in on your hair or your skin it feels OILY, because it's SUPPOSED TO. It's meant to be used very sparingly and will, after a minute or two, be absorbed, to an extent determined by the exterior dryness of the hair or skin, by the upper layers of<br /> the skin and thecortex of the hair. In Morocco and elsewhere in north Africa, the oil is left in the hair. The Western preference for hair that isn't &#34;weighed down&#34; by products means that argan in the hair is more useful as a pre-shampoo treatment. Remember, though, that if you aggressively shampoo the areas of the hair where you've used the argan oil, you will basically wash it all out. Using it on the ends of the hair and shampooing the ends lightly will allow some of the oil to remain and will leave a soft finish there; using the oil as a scalp massage overnight and then washing well in the morning will help alleviate dry, itchy scalp.<br /> Argan oil is a wonderful moisturizer for hair and skin, but PLEASE understand what it is, how it is made and how to use it. PLEASE save your money and don't waste it on products like this which essentially exploit the &#34;exotic&#34; quality of a product from a third-world culture but in fact sell nothing more than cheap, readily available (though highly effective, and the EXACT SAME whether in expensive or drugstore products) chemicals produced by the millions of gallons in factories here and abroad. USE THE MONEY YOU SAVE BY NOT PURCHASING THESE FAKE PRODUCTS TO CONTRIBUTE TO A CHARITABLE ORGANIZATION OF YOUR CHOICE THAT ASSISTS THIRD-WORLD CITIZENS IN BETTERING THEIR LIVES. And if you want &#34;real&#34; argan oil in this country, you'll have to pay a tremendous amount for it. Josie Maran and a couple other cosmetic purveyors offer actual argan oil at the cost of about 89 dollars for 1.7 ounces.
  1361. Best hair oil. Bottom line. Smells great. You only need a very very tiny bit. It's amazing.

If you use too much of it will weigh your hair down a little or make it too soft. A little goes a long way and this is fantastic!

  1375. Due to heat tools, the ends of my hair have become extremely brittle and dry. I had to get extra hair cut off at my last hair appointment and was extremely disappointed in the shape of my hair - also knowing that it would continue to dry out if I didn't make a change. After reading the reviews from Amazon, I decided to splurge and purchase this product. WELL WORTH IT! I have been using the oil for approximately a week and have noticed a HUGE difference in the health of my hair. I have naturally thin hair and hate that most products always seem to weigh it down - not this one. I squeeze the smallest amount into the palms of my hands and work it through the ends of my damp hair post-shower first, then finger comb the rest through the rest of my hair. Overall, my hair has become noticeably softer and visibly looks healthier. I've also noticed that without even using the product, my hair has been extremely easy to comb through and much more manageable.<br /><br />Although the price can be scary at first, it is a great investment! I'm excited to continue to use this product and see how the rest of the results turn out. Plenty of my friends have started to use it and love it as well.

  1385. I have always heard amazing things about argan oil helping with hair, skin, face, etc. I have been struggling with keeping my dry hair smooth. It's been tangling and it's so dry and coarse, I can never run hair fingers through my hair. I can even hear my hair crunch in between my fingers- that's how dry my hair is! I've never chemically treated my hair BUT I do blow dry my hair after showers since my hair is so thick and takes a long time drying. I finally received a small bottle of the Moroccan Oil, after voicing my dissatisfaction with all the other hair softening serums, from a friend. Since it is an oil, I don't use a whole lot. I just take one of my fingers and I just cover the opening and I tilt bottle for oil to come out and I just rub it on the ends of my hair. Start from the middle point of your hair and stroke downwards to make hair ends smoother. I didn't care to have this oil on my scalp since I worry it will make my head greasy. The oil is very aromatic so if you don't favor smells then this might be a no for you. But I like the smell so it's ok! Might be a tad pricey but it's worth it.

  1391. The product that I received in the mail today, while claiming to be Moroccan Oil Hair Treatment, was most certainly NOT Moroccan Oil Hair Treatment.<br /><br />Clue #1: The smell. The awful, awful smell. The liquid in this bottle smelled like grandma's perfume, not like the light, jasmine-y scent of authentic Moroccan Oil. Gross.<br />Clue #2: The appearance. The thick, cloudy liquid in this bottle looked more like honey, and less like the clear, light, medium-viscosity Moroccan Oil. Come on.<br />Clue #3: The packaging. The box looked beat up and weathered. And the bottle! The bottle had clearly been opened and re-glued, as evidenced by the stringy, booger-like glue that you find when you peel a brand new credit card off the mailer that it came in. And, while this glue is fun to play with, I don't want it in, on, or near my hair products.<br /><br />I've been using Moroccan Oil Hair Treatment for years, and I'm no dummy. You're not fooling anyone. And if it wasn't for Amazon's restriction on returning items of this type, I'd be sending this product back faster than you can say \\"FAKE.\\"
